text: And I will make my covenant between me and thee, and will multiply thee exceedingly .
text_kjv: And I will make my covenant between me and thee, and will multiply thee exceedingly .
text_niv: I will confirm my covenant between me and you and will greatly increase your numbers.”
text_esv: that I may make my covenant between me and you, and may multiply you greatly.”
text_nlt: I will make a covenant with you, by which I will guarantee to give you countless descendants.”
text_msg: I'll make a covenant between us and I'll give you a huge family."
text_nasb: 'I will establish My covenant between Me and you, And I will multiply you exceedingly.'
context: Genesis 17 occurs within the patriarchal narratives, a period understood primarily through the lens of the Hebrew Bible. Abraham (Abram until this chapter) lived in a world dominated by polytheistic religions and city-states in Mesopotamia. Covenants were common in the ancient Near East, often between kings and vassals, solidifying power and loyalty. However, these covenants typically involved sacrifices, oaths, and specific performance obligations from both parties. God's covenant with Abraham differed significantly; it was initiated solely by God, highlighting his sovereignty and grace. Abram, at this point, was 99 years old, childless through Sarah and likely feeling the weight of age and unfulfilled promises. The changing of Abram's name to Abraham ('father of many nations') and Sarai's name to Sarah ('princess') signified a pivotal shift in their identities and destinies, prefiguring their roles in God's unfolding plan. Circumcision was instituted as a physical sign of the covenant, marking Abraham's descendants as distinct and set apart for God's purpose. The promise of multiplication was particularly significant in a culture where lineage and progeny were highly valued, ensuring societal continuity and strength. The verse must be understood against this backdrop of ancient Near Eastern customs, the importance of covenant relationships, and the specific challenges Abraham faced in trusting God's promise despite his advanced age and lack of an heir.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 17:2 is a pivotal verse in understanding the Abrahamic Covenant, which forms a foundational element of both Judaism and Christianity. The phrase 'I will make my covenant between me and thee' emphasizes God's initiative and sovereign power. This is not a negotiation but a divinely ordained promise. The word 'covenant' (Hebrew: *berit*) implies a binding agreement, but in this case, one unilaterally established by God. It underscores the grace and unconditional nature of God's relationship with Abraham. The second part of the verse, 'and will multiply thee exceedingly,' highlights the promise of abundant blessing and posterity. This promise extends beyond merely having numerous descendants; it signifies a multiplication of spiritual influence, a blessing that would extend to all nations through Abraham's lineage (as later confirmed in Genesis 22:18). The promise of multiplication is inextricably linked to the covenant itself. It is not merely a consequence of Abraham's obedience but an inherent aspect of God's design. It points forward to the fulfillment of God's redemptive plan for humanity, culminating in the coming of Jesus Christ, who is considered the ultimate seed of Abraham. Thus, the verse speaks to God's faithfulness, his commitment to his promises, and his intention to bless the world through Abraham's line.
application: In contemporary life, Genesis 17:2 offers several practical applications for believers. First, it encourages us to trust in God's promises, even when circumstances seem impossible. Like Abraham, we may face situations where our own abilities and resources are inadequate. This verse reminds us that God's power is not limited by our limitations. Second, the covenant underscores the importance of a personal relationship with God. Just as God established a covenant with Abraham, he offers a covenant relationship to each of us through Jesus Christ. This relationship is based on grace, not on our own merit or performance. Third, the promise of multiplication should inspire us to live lives that have a positive impact on others. We are called to be a blessing to those around us, sharing the love and grace of God. This can involve acts of service, words of encouragement, or simply living a life that reflects God's character. Fourth, the verse challenges us to consider our own legacy. What kind of impact do we want to have on future generations? Are we investing our time, talents, and resources in ways that will honor God and bless others? Fifth, the verse highlights the importance of perseverance. Abraham waited many years for the fulfillment of God's promise, and he faced numerous challenges along the way. Similarly, we may face trials and setbacks as we seek to live out our faith. This verse encourages us to remain steadfast and trust in God's timing and provision. Finally, it calls believers to recognize that their identity is intricately tied to God's covenant. Just as Abraham was marked by circumcision as a sign of the covenant, believers are marked by the Holy Spirit as a seal of their relationship with God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your unwavering faithfulness and your boundless love. We are humbled by your gracious covenant with Abraham and the promise of multiplication that flows through his lineage. Lord, help us to trust in your promises, even when we face challenges and uncertainties. Empower us to live lives that reflect your character and bring blessing to others. Grant us the wisdom to invest our time, talents, and resources in ways that will honor you and leave a lasting impact on future generations. Strengthen our faith and perseverance, that we may remain steadfast in our commitment to you. Help us to recognize our identity as your covenant people, sealed by your Spirit. May our lives be a testament to your goodness and grace. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: In Abraham's time, lineage and progeny held immense cultural and societal significance. Children ensured the continuation of the family name, provided support in old age, and increased the tribe's strength. Childlessness was often seen as a curse or a sign of divine disapproval. Thus, the promise of 'multiplication' directly addressed Abraham's deepest concern and signified God's blessing and favor in a very tangible way, contradicting cultural norms.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why is the promise of 'multiplication' so important in this specific context?

faqs.answer: The phrasing 'between me and thee' highlights the unilateral nature of the covenant. God is the initiator and guarantor. While Abraham is expected to be obedient and faithful, the covenant's validity and blessings are ultimately dependent on God's character and commitment, not on Abraham's perfect performance. This emphasizes God's grace and sovereignty.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean that the covenant is 'between me and thee' rather than a two-way agreement?

faqs.answer: The promise of multiplication in Genesis 17:2 finds its ultimate fulfillment in Jesus Christ. He is the 'seed' of Abraham through whom all nations are blessed (Galatians 3:16). The New Covenant established through Jesus offers salvation and eternal life to all who believe, extending the blessings of Abraham's covenant to a global audience.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the New Testament and the covenant through Jesus Christ?

faqs.answer: Spiritually 'multiplying' involves sharing our faith, discipling others, and investing in the lives of those around us. It includes using our gifts and talents to serve God and build up the church, supporting missions and outreach efforts, and living a life that is a witness to God's grace and love.
faqs.question: Q4: What are some practical ways we can 'multiply' in a spiritual sense today?

faqs.answer: The promise of multiplication is not a guarantee of a life free from suffering. Rather, it speaks to God's ability to bring good out of hardship and to use our trials for his glory. Even in the midst of suffering, we can experience God's blessing and see our lives used to impact others positively.
faqs.question: Q5: How can we reconcile this promise of multiplication with the reality of suffering and hardship in the world?
